ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained insights into the work of my fellow art majors, which was always awesome. Some of the visiting artists were great.

I learned plenty about the next steps for an artist after college. I learned about the reality of basic income for an artist and having to juggle that responsibility with working an actual job. In addition, it was beneficial to hear from professional artists and critics about their own work and experience.
I developed my ability to talk more about different disciplines in art.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The single purpose of this class is to get the art majors up to speed with one another and talking with each other. Given that, I think there could be more moments for concerted dialogue, even outside of each person's presentation. Maybe we make art together or something.

It was interesting to hear about everyones backgrounds and theses, however I was not a fan of the speakers brought in for career workshops. They were all gallery workers which is one narrow sector of the art world. I wish there was more variety in the professions of the speakers.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This class is required for seniors majoring in Art or Computing and the Arts (Art Track), so they must take it.
You have to take it as an art major.
